content: Hokkien and Teochew dish widely adapted in Malay and Indonesia **Ngo hiang** ([Hokkien](/wiki/Hokkien) [Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_language): 五香; [Pe̍h-ōe-jī](/wiki/Pe%CC%8Dh-%C5%8De-j%C4%AB): *ngó͘-hiang / ngó͘-hiong / gó͘-hiong*), also known as **heh gerng** ([Chinese](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters): 蝦管; [Pe̍h-ōe-jī](/wiki/Pe%CC%8Dh-%C5%8De-j%C4%AB): *hê-kǹg*) **lor bak** ([Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_language): 五香滷肉; [Pe̍h-ōe-jī](/wiki/Pe%CC%8Dh-%C5%8De-j%C4%AB): *ngó͘-hiong-ló͘-bah*) or **kikiam** (Tagalog pronunciation: [ˈkɪk.jam]) is a unique [Hokkien](/wiki/Hoklo_people) and [Teochew](/wiki/Teochew_cuisine) dish widely adopted in [Indonesia](/wiki/Indonesia), [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia), the [Philippines](/wiki/Philippines), [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore), and [Thailand](/wiki/Thailand), in addition to its place of origin in southern [China](/wiki/China). It is essentially a composition of various meats and vegetables and other ingredients, such as a [sausage](/wiki/Sausage)-like roll consisting of minced pork and prawn (or fish) seasoned with [five-spice powder](/wiki/Five-spice_powder) ([Hokkien](/wiki/Hokkien): [Chinese](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_characters): 五香粉, *ngó͘-hiong-hún*) after which it is named, rolled inside a [tofu skin](/wiki/Tofu_skin) and deep-fried. It is usually served with [chili sauce](/wiki/Chili_sauce) and a house-special sweet sauce. Many stalls in Singaporean [food courts](/wiki/Food_courts) and [hawker centres](/wiki/Hawker_centre) sell fried [bee hoon](/wiki/Bee_hoon) with ngo hiang; this combination is common for breakfast and lunch. In Indonesia, people enjoy ngo hiang with [sambal](/wiki/Sambal). The Philippine versions were originally introduced by Hokkien migrants and are generally known as kikiam. However, the variant called [ngohiong](/wiki/Ngohiong) from [Cebu](/wiki/Cebu) has diverged significantly from the original dish. Instead of using beancurd skin, it uses [lumpia](/wiki/Lumpia) wrappers. A street food dish also sometimes called "kikiam" (called "tempura" in Cebu) in the Philippines is neither of those dishes, but is instead an elongated version of [fishballs](/wiki/Fishball). The street food version of kikiam was made from pork, not fish. ## 2019 Southeast Asian Games controversies During the [2019 Southeast Asian Games](/wiki/2019_Southeast_Asian_Games) in the Philippines, a report from the *[South China Morning Post](/wiki/South_China_Morning_Post)* on 26 November 2019 claimed that [Muslim](/wiki/Muslims) athletes from [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore) were served *kikiam* and pork rolls, both containing [ground pork](/wiki/Ground_meat) which [Muslims are prohibited from consuming](/wiki/Religious_restrictions_on_the_consumption_of_pork#Prohibition_in_Islamic_law). The report, however, was refuted by the [Singapore National Olympic Council](/wiki/Singapore_National_Olympic_Council), stating that the Muslim athletes on the Singaporean team were not served pork to eat. On the same day, another incident occurred after the coach of the [Philippine women's football team](/wiki/Philippines_women%27s_national_football_team) complained that the athletes were only served *kikiam* with rice and egg for breakfast at the hotel that they stayed in. The hotel clarified, however, that the *kikiam* was actually chicken sausage, and was part of a buffet service that included other food as well. It was also revealed that the coach was not actually at the hotel when the incident happened. Following this, the coach apologized to the hotel for the error. ## Gallery - Food portal - [Batagor](/wiki/Batagor) - [Fishcake](/wiki/Fishcake) - [Lekor](/wiki/Lekor) - [Otak-otak](/wiki/Otak-otak) - [Pempek](/wiki/Pempek)
